pageContext.claim: “I feel badly for General Flynn. He's lost his house. He's lost his life. And some people say he lied, and some people say he didn't lie. I mean, really, it turned out maybe he didn't lie. So how can you do that?”
pageContext.analysis: Trump has said repeatedly that he dismissed Michael Flynn for lying. The president asked for and accepted the resignation of his first national security adviser on Feb. 13, 2017. Days later, Trump said he had fired Flynn for providing incomplete information to Vice President Pence about his contacts with the Russian ambassador, Sergei Kislyak. In December 2017, the president tweeted, "I had to fire General Flynn because he lied to the Vice President and the FBI." Flynn has pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI about his contacts with Kislyak.
